title: 109_hr5092
content:
The Act is titled the "Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (BATFE) Modernization and Reform Act of 2006". It includes provisions for graduated penalties for civil violations by federal firearms licensees. The "BATFE Modernization and Reform Act of 2006" amends Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allowing the Attorney General to impose civil money penalties or suspend licenses for violations by federal firearms licensees. The "BATFE Modernization and Reform Act of 2006" allows the Attorney General to impose civil money penalties or suspend licenses for violations by federal firearms licensees, with penalties of up to $2,500 per violation and license suspension for up to 90 days for serious violations. The "BATFE Modernization and Reform Act of 2006" allows the Attorney General to impose civil money penalties or suspend licenses for violations by federal firearms licensees. The penalties can be up to $2,500 per violation and license suspension for up to 90 days for serious violations. In determining the amount of a civil money penalty, the nature and severity of the violation, the size of the firearms business, and the licensee's prior record are considered. The Attorney General may also consider the licensee's ability to pay and allow them to submit documents to establish their ability to pay. The "BATFE Modernization and Reform Act of 2006" allows the Attorney General to impose civil money penalties or suspend licenses for violations by federal firearms licensees. Penalties for violations of a minor or serious nature during a single inspection cannot exceed $15,000. Violation of a provision with respect to multiple firearms in a single transaction is considered a single violation. The Attorney General has the authority to defer or suspend civil money penalties for licensees with suspended licenses. A violation is considered serious if it could result in the transfer of a firearm or ammunition to a person. The Attorney General may impose civil money penalties or suspend licenses for violations by federal firearms licensees, including obstructing investigations or preventing compliance with firearm transfer regulations. Violations are categorized as minor or serious, with penalties not exceeding $15,000 for a single inspection. The Attorney General may not enforce penalties for violations by federal firearms licensees after a 5-year period from the date of the violation. Before imposing a penalty, the licensee must be notified of the grounds and given the opportunity to request a hearing for review. The Attorney General must stay any penalty imposed on a licensee pending a review, unless there is clear evidence of immediate public safety threat. The licensee has 30 days to request a hearing for review, and the review must be resolved within 90 days of the request. The Attorney General and the licensee agree on a later time for a hearing with an administrative law judge to review a determination. The Attorney General must provide the licensee with a list of witnesses, evidence, and documents before the hearing. Within 90 days after the hearing, the judge will issue a decision on whether to affirm, modify, or reverse the determination. The Attorney General can stay any penalty imposed on the licensee upon request. The Attorney General can stay penalties, suspensions, or revocations upon request of the licensee until a final judgment is made. An administrative law judge's decision is final and can only be reviewed as provided in subsection (f). This subsection does not affect the Attorney General's authority under section 922(t)(5). Within 60 days of receiving a notice of a decision to deny a license or impose a penalty, a party can file a petition for a de novo review in the United States district court. The court will consider any evidence submitted by the parties, and if it finds the decision was not authorized, the Attorney General will be ordered to comply with the court's judgment. The Attorney General is barred from denying, suspending, or revoking a license, or imposing a civil money penalty if a licensee is acquitted of criminal charges related to the same facts. The Attorney General cannot take action to suspend or revoke a license or impose a civil money penalty more than 1 year after the filing of an indictment or information. The Attorney General is prohibited from taking action against a licensee if they are acquitted of criminal charges related to the same facts. The Attorney General cannot suspend or revoke a license more than 1 year after the filing of an indictment or information. Additionally, if an application for a license is denied, an administrative law judge will hold a hearing upon request by the aggrieved party to review the denial. If the denial is upheld, the administrative law judge will notify the aggrieved party of the final decision. SEC. 3. CONSIDERATION OF FEDERAL FIREARMS LICENSE APPLICATIONS. The Attorney General will make a preliminary determination on firearm license applications, notifying applicants of the decision and reasons. Applicants can supplement their application with more information and request a hearing if the initial determination is to deny the application. If a hearing is requested, it will be held at a convenient location for the applicant. The Attorney General will notify applicants of preliminary decisions on firearm license applications and allow them to request a hearing. Section 923(f) of the title is amended to reflect changes made by the Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF WILLFULLY.

    The term 'willfully' is defined as knowingly engaging in conduct in intentional disregard of a legal duty.

SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF FORMAL INSPECTION, EXAMINATION, AND INVESTIGATIVE GUIDELINES.

    The Attorney General will establish guidelines for conducting inspections, examinations, or investigations of possible violations of specific chapters in the United States Code.

SEC. 6. REVIEW BY THE INSPECTOR GENERAL OF THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE OF THE GUN SHOW ENFORCEMENT PROGRAM; REPORT. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice will review the operations of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives regarding the gun show enforcement program and residency checks of firearms purchasers. A report with findings and recommendations must be submitted to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees within one year. SEC. 7. LIMITATIONS ON USE OF FIREARMS PURCHASER INFORMATION. Amends Section 923(g)(1)(D) of title 18, United States Code to restrict the disclosure of information on individuals who have purchased firearms or ammunition and are not prohibited from doing so. Information can only be disclosed to specific law enforcement entities. SEC. 8. LIQUIDATION OF INVENTORY IN FEDERAL FIREARMS LICENSE EXPIRATION, SURRENDER, OR REVOCATION CASES. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow a 60-day period for individuals with expired, surrendered, or revoked firearms licenses to liquidate their inventory, with the possibility of extension for reasonable cause. The license remains valid during this period unless a court determines that the business poses a serious threat to public safety. SEC. 9. OPPORTUNITY TO CURE VIOLATIONS AFTER ACQUISITION OF FIREARMS BUSINESS. Amends Section 923 of title 18, United States Code to allow notification of violations to new owners of firearms businesses transferred due to death, bankruptcy, or assignment for creditors, without presuming the new owner's involvement in the violation. SEC. 10 amends Section 922(m) of title 18, United States Code by changing references to false entries to materially false entries, appropriate entries to materially significant entries, and properly maintain to retain custody of. SEC. 11 grants authority to collect information on explosives stored under state law and applies regulations governing storage of explosives to agencies operating under state law. Authority is granted to agencies operating under state law to submit written reports to the Attorney General specifying the locations and details of explosive materials stored. The Attorney General must prescribe regulations within six months of the enactment of this section. Regulations in section 846(c) of title 18, US Code apply to storage of explosive materials by agencies under state law. Subpart K of part 555 of title 27, Code of Federal Regulations, applies to storage of explosive materials transported in interstate or foreign commerce by state agencies. SEC. 12. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
